Which users can sign in to VM1, and which users can sign in to VM2? To answer, select the appropriate options in the answer area.

NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.

//IMG//

discussion.content:
Correct!
The Virtual Machine Contributor role in Azure allows users to manage virtual machines, including actions like creating, deleting, and configuring VMs. However, it does not grant permissions to log into the virtual machine itself

To log into a VM, you would need the Virtual Machine Administrator Login or Virtual Machine User Login roles

Answer provided is correct.

VM1: User1 and User3 only, because User1 has a role scope for the entire subscription (which includes the resource group named RG1) and User3 to VM1. Also, both of their roles allow the users to login into the VM.

VM2: Only User1, because User2 has the "Virtual Machine Contributor" role and that does not allow login to any VM and User3 is limited to VM1 for access.

The subscription contains a Conditional Access policy that has the following settings:

• Name: Policy1
• Assignments
o Include
- Users and Groups: Group1
- Directory roles: Global Administrator
o Exclude
- Users and Groups: Group2
o Target resources
- Include
- All cloud apps
- Access controls
- Grant
- Require multifactor authentication

For each of the following statements, select Yes if the statement is true. Otherwise, select No.

NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.

//IMG//

discussion.content: YNY (same as others mentioned). Reason being conditional access first apply inclusions, then apply exclusions. Exclusions overlap inclusions and take precedence.

I think Y/N/Y

The policy includes all users, but excludes group 2 (so user2 and user3)

User1 - is explicitly asked for MFA
User2 - is excluded, so no MFA requirement
User3 - is excluded but has admin role, all admins are required to use MFA unless specified otherwise, the policy is not supposed to bypass this (I think)

Y N Y 
Direct assignments take precedence over exclusions.

Key Rule:
✅ If a user is included via a group and also a member of an excluded group, they are excluded.
❌ If a user is directly assigned, exclusions do not apply.

If Global Administrator was both members of Group1 (included) and Group2 (excluded), then both would be excluded from the policy because his inclusion comes from group membership, and exclusions apply to users included via groups. Since Global Administrator is directly assigned via directory role, the exclusion does not apply, and he will still receive the policy.

Explanation from MS docs:
FRAUD ALERT 
The fraud alert feature lets users report fraudulent attempts to access their resources. When an unknown and suspicious MFA prompt is received, users can report the fraud attempt by using the Microsoft Authenticator app or through their phone.
The following fraud alert configuration options are available:
- Automatically block users who report fraud.
- Code to report fraud during initial greeting. 

BLOCK AND UNBLOCK USERS
If a user's device is lost or stolen, you can block Azure AD Multi-Factor Authentication attempts for the associated account. Any Azure AD Multi-Factor Authentication attempts for blocked users are automatically denied. Users remain blocked for 90 days from the time that they're blocked.
